Name: Pham Minh Khanh

Class: BA

Lecturer: Phan Dinh Tram Anh

Student code: CS

Idividual Assignment

IA 1 : Use 2 real examples to prove principle # 4 is true. Principle #4: People

respond to incentives (chapter 1).

IA 2 : Use 2 real examples to prove principle #9 is true. Principle #9: Prices rise

when the government prints too much money (chapter 1).

Example 1 : Hungary.

On November 12, 1918, after separating from the Austro-Hungarian Empire,

Hungary for the first time had its own currency, the kronen. In 1921, the Hungarian

parliament passed the Hegedüs reform, which imposed a 20% tax on bank

deposits. Ultimately, the Hungarian government had to print money

uncontrollably, leading to inflation reaching 98% each month. To end the inflation

situation, the government decided to eliminate the kronen and issue the pengő in

1927. When World War II broke out, Hungary's economy was very weak,

agriculture and infrastructure were damaged. severe destruction. To meet budget

needs, the government printed money uncontrollably, and the value of the pengő

also fell to the bottom and could not recover, even after the war ended. In 1944, the

highest denomination in the country This is 1,000 pengő. By the end of 1945, that

number had reached 10 million pengő. Prices began to increase rapidly, according

to Business Insider: "In Budapest, an item that cost 379 pengos in September 1945

would have to be bought for 72,330 pengos in January 1946; 453,886 pengő in

February; 1,872,910 pengő in March; 35,790,276 pengő in April; 11,267 million

pengő on May 31; 862 billion pengő on June 15; 954 billion pengő on June 30; 3

billion pengő on July 7; 11 trillion pengő on July 15; and 1 trillion trillion pengő

on July 22.” This causes the Hungarian government to use currency units that are

constantly increasing. Pengő was replaced by special new currency units: mpengő

(1 mpengő = 1 million pengő), bpengő (1 bpengő = 1 billion pengő) and adópengő

were issued for paying taxes and postage 1945 , Hungary issued notes worth

25 billion pengő. By January 1946, this figure increased to 1,646 trillion pengő, in

May it was 65 trillion pengő and in July it was 47 trillion pengő until the

government ran out of paper to print money. The banknote with the highest

denomination of 100 billion pengő was printed around mid-1946. In August 1946,

Hungary decided to abolish the pengő and special currency units based on it to

start over from scratch. dilapidated. A new currency, the forint, was issued at an

exchange rate of 1 to 400,000 quadrillion pengő (after 4 there are 29 zeros).

Fortunately, Hungary's economic situation has gradually become stable. Currently,

the forint has officially been banned. replaced by the Euro from 2020 according to

commitments in the roadmap to join the European Union (EU).

Example 2 : Germany.

In 1914, when World War I broke out, 1 USD could now be exchanged for 4.

marks, because paying for war and weapons was beyond the government's

calculations. In November 1922, the value of gold coins in circulation in Germany

fell from 300 million pounds (before World War I) to 20 million pounds. The

Reichbank came up with a solution: uncontrolled printing of the Mark currency,

thereby accelerating the devaluation of the Mark. By December 1922, 1 USD

could still be exchanged for 2,000 marks, but by April 1923 That number increased

to 20,000 marks for 1 USD and by August it was over 1 million marks. In 1923,

the inflation rate increased by 3 × 106% per month (prices doubled every 2

days). Germany fell into its worst situation in October 1923, when the inflation rate

reached 29%. And by November 1923, this figure had increased to 238 million

marks. At its peak in December 1923, 1 USD was equivalent to 4,200 billion

marks, an estimated inflation rate of 750 billion%. From November 20, 1923, the

Mark was replaced by the Rentenmark (RM) at the rate of 1 thousand. billion

Marks to 1 RM. The new exchange rate would be 4 RM to 1 USD, the same as

the exchange rate of the Mark in 1914. Finally, on August 30, 1924, the

rentenmark became the official currency and the currency began to have value

again.
